docs.snippet: Microsoft, once the No. 1 antitrust defendant, takes the other side -- and there are lessons for Google in Microsoft's experience....
docs.lead_paragraph: Business and law are pragmatic vocations. So where a company stands on some principle typically hinges on the circumstances in which it sits. Just ask Microsoft, long the world's No. 1 antitrust defendant, that on Thursday filed a formal antitrust complaint in Europe against Google, as we reported.

headline.main: Microsoft's Antitrust Volley and Google's Way Forward

docs.snippet: In the movie ''Fight Club,'' Tyler Durden, the character played by Brad Pitt, says, ''The first rule of fight club is you do not talk about fight club.''     The same rule, by and large, has applied to the architecture of cloud computing - the mas...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the movie ''Fight Club,'' Tyler Durden, the character played by Brad Pitt, says, ''The first rule of fight club is you do not talk about fight club.'' The same rule, by and large, has applied to the architecture of cloud computing - the massive, energy-hungry data centers and servers that power services like Google, Facebook, Twitter and Amazon, which companies treat as proprietary secrets. But Facebook is opening the design of its custom-built servers and soon-to-be new data center in Oregon to others in the industry.

headline.main: Facebook Shares Some Server Secrets

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Facebook is opening design of its custom-built servers and forthcoming data center in Oregon to others in industry; photo (S)

headline.main: How Useful Is Google’s Personalized Search?

docs.abstract: Google’s experiments with adding friends’ recommendations to search results begin to pay off.

docs.snippet: Taj Melendez’s Atari-esque series of bead brooches and barrettes may just be the new fashion accessory must-have....
docs.lead_paragraph: During the recent New York fashion shows, the blogger Hanneli Mustaparta posted a snapshot of Andreea Diaconu wearing a panda bear brooch that looked like a relic from the Atari age. After numerous Google searches (no luck), inquisitive e-mails (no luck) and one (lucky) Facebook search, we found the maker of the pin: 19-year-old Taj Melendez in Brooklyn, New York. “During art class in elementary school, we would do projects like these with perler beads,” says Melendez, who, like Space Invader, the street artist with a similar aesthetic, seems to shy away from attention rather than seek it out. He made his first pin, a replica of the men’s restroom icon, when he was 16. “I just wanted to start something, I wanted to stand out.” He sells his designs — bow ties, barrettes and an assortment of brooches like a thought bubble or a football — through his Web site ($55 to $75; go to bytaj.com). “I want to keep them special — that’s why I don’t create too many too fast.” When asked how Diaconu got her hands on that darling panda face, he shrugs with disbelief. “I have no idea,” he says. “But I sure was happy.”

headline.main: Lapel Invader

docs.abstract: Taj Melendez’s Atari-esque series of bead brooches and barrettes may just be the new fashion accessory must-have.

docs.snippet: Google updated its YouTube copyright policy on Thursday, and will begin requiring users who break copyright law to attend a “Copyright School” on the Web site....
docs.lead_paragraph: In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in the boys room in high school: You’re forced to take an online class at YouTube’s Copyright School.

headline.main: YouTube Sentences Copyright Offenders to School

docs.abstract: Google updated its YouTube copyright policy on Thursday, and will begin requiring users who break copyright law to attend a “Copyright School” on the Web site.

docs.snippet: Google Maps’ visual equivalent to “you are here.”...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google’s maps have revolutionized how we interact with the world, how we perceive space and even how we navigate through it. Type in a location, and down drops a red marker, or “map pin,” that answers any question of place. Outfitted with its own drop shadow, the small, red bubble with a pointed end not only tells us where we want to be, but what exists in the world around us.

headline.main: Who Made Google’s Map Pin?

docs.abstract: Google Maps’ visual equivalent to “you are here.”

docs.snippet: In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in th...
docs.lead_paragraph: In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in the boys room in high school: You're forced to take an online class at YouTube's Copyright School. Copyright School isn't your normal edition of detention. Copyright violators are asked to watch a four-and-a-half minute minute video and then required to take a multiple choice quiz that asks questions pertaining to copyright. One question, for example, asks if music videos and photographs fall under copyright protection.

headline.main: Sent to Copyright School at Youtube

docs.abstract: Bits blog; people who violate copyright infringement laws on YouTube will be asked to take an online class at YouTube's Copyright School; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eric E. Schmidt's new job as executive chairman of Google came with a very nice raise. Mr. Schmidt, who as chief executive of Google had been earning just $1 a year since 2005 (though his ownership stake in the company is worth several billion dollars), will now earn $1.25 million a year with a potential $6 million annual bonus, according to a regulatory filing Tuesday by Google.

headline.main: Google Executive Gets a Raise at Last

docs.snippet: Q.Yesterday I received e-mail from a friend in North Carolina discussing the effects of a recent tornado. On the side (not in actual message) were sites for some cities near my friend. Is Google snooping in my messages? I am not pleased.     A.Lik...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q.Yesterday I received e-mail from a friend in North Carolina discussing the effects of a recent tornado. On the side (not in actual message) were sites for some cities near my friend. Is Google snooping in my messages? I am not pleased. A.Like other free Web-mail services, Google uses advertising to help support the cost of Gmail. To make the ad links more enticing, Gmail uses targeted ads that are often related to the places or topics mentioned within your messages.

headline.main: Personalized Ads in Gmail
